abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the
            project's achievement of the major objectives is
            satisfactory. The project significantly contributed to
            establishing an institutional capacity to identify and
            develop environmental policies and programs at the federal
            and state levels. The project funded and guided the creation
            of a monitoring network for data gathering and dissemination
            of detailed information. During the project's life, an
            enormous amount of work was done to develop dialogue and
            linkages with a wide range of government and community
            representatives, significantly raising public awareness and
            understanding of environmental problems. Also, the large
            numbers of staff trained by the project in the various
            agencies should continue to have an impact on national
            policies and programs. A central lesson learned is the
            overarching importance in a complex technical assistance
            project for effective management and close supervision at
            the field level. The decisions required to move ahead with
            project activities needed to be more decentralized from the
            outset to give the project units within each agency more
            authority for procuring goods and services. The World Bank
            should have had substantial resources in the Resident
            Mission from the initial stages to provide adequate ongoing
            supervision and support to move with the project as it
            developed, and to ensure agency coordination. The
            project's planned implementation period was too
            short--although the project closing date was later extended.
